Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Algebraic and Combinatorial Structures In Complexity Theory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The influence that computers have on our daily lives is enabled by efficient algorithms. A vast body of research is devoted to algorithmic design, but we still cannot solve most of the important computational problems that arise in science and engineering. This is captured by the famous P vs NP problem in computational complexity, which is the most important mathematical problem of our times.

In this project, the PI describes a plan to address some of the challenges of computational complexity by exploring deep mathematical questions about algebraic and combinatorial structures and their applications to fundamental problems in computer science. Specifically, the focus of this proposal is on two mathematical themes: (1) low rank and combinatorial structure in matrices and (2) structure of low-degree polynomials. The unified view of the common mathematical framework allows us to relate techniques, results and problems between seemingly unrelated fields in computer science, such as: algorithm design, communication protocols, error correcting codes, de-randomization, and computational lower bounds. This research is also tightly related to some fundamental problems in mathematics, in particular in combinatorics and number theory.

The PI plans to organize interdisciplinary workshops that will bring together researchers in complexity theory and other disciplines in order to learn and collaborate. The educational plans are integrated with the research and include undergraduate and graduate course development, experimentation with innovative instructional approaches, in particular the flipped classroom, mentoring of students, and outreach to engage pre-college students from diverse socio-economic backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to better understand several open problems in theoretical computer science, based on investigating their combinatorial and algebraic structure. The outcome is that this types of structure are indeed extremely useful, and indeed several well-studied open problems have been resolved based on this realization. Below are some key examples:

* Coding theory studies error correcting codes, which are used to recover from errors in communication and storage. Results in the award used algebraic and combinatorial structure to resolve decades-old open problems about Reed-Muller codes, which are some of the most commonly studied and used codes. In addition, we resolved a more recent conjecture (the MDS conjecture) about the combinatorial and algebraic structure of codes used for distributed storage.

* Computational complexity studies the relative hardness of many algorithmic problems. Unfortunately, a lot of the research on the central open problems (such as circuit lower bounds) seems to be stuck. As part of this award, we gave an explanation for this phenomena. It turns out that the existing techniques can be extended to apply to a more general class of objects, called nonclassical polynomials, which originally arose in number theory (and which the PI helped to develop the theory for). However, for these nonclassical polynomials, the current bounds provably cannot be improved.

* Active learning is a sub-area of machine learning, where a learning algorithm is given a a large amount of unlabelled data, and needs to smartly choose a small subset of the data to label. As part of this award, we designed significantly better active learning algorithms, based on combinatorial structure of the data. Then, re-interpreting these algorithms in the language of computational geometry, we used it to resolve open problems on the non-uniform complexity of certain central problems in the area (such as 3-SUM).

The common theme is that all of these results build upon understanding either combinatorial structure, algebraic structure, or both, in the relevant domain.
